comments.author: Kiki1986

comments.text:
Sarma is made of fermented cabbage leaves in Balkans (sarma made of 
wine/grape leaves is called Greek-sarma here, at least that's how we call 
it in some parts of Serbia). Also, we use pork meat, but you can try to mix 
lamb and calf meat or lamb with beef and ad some spices in fillings like 
garlic and onion and dried/dehydrated parsley and of course salt and 
pepper. The filling is also better if you braise it first with onion and 
garlic and pepper (the vegetable, not the spice; if you can find 
dried/dehydrated powdered red pepper, sweet or hot, use it, but be careful 
with the hot pepper). Put some dried/dehydrated laurel leaves by the end of 
cooking on top of the wrapped sarmas (not in the fillings) and it'll taste 
better, 2 or 3 leaves, don't overdo it. Also, if you have some smoked meat, 
put it at the begging of cooking, side by side, with the wrapped sarmas. 
It'll be more delicious. 

There is also the sarma made of walnut and dried/dehydrated and smoked 
plums or apricots (we put it in the fillings with rice; we also put rice in 
the fillings of the meat-sarma). We make it when we fast. I don't know the 
recipe for it, I think my friend does, because we eat it when we celebrate 
his slava (a sort of family holiday, religious type of holiday), because 
it's on the day when the christian fast. It's very, very delicious, you 
wouldn't believe it.
comments.author: upakaosnjim

top_comment.text:
Romania is not a balkan country, but we have most of those in here too.

Kefir - it's very popular, actually I drank some yesterday :).We write it 
as ''chefir'' and we also have something similar called ''sana''.

Sarma - we call them here the same, but we use the plural form when we 
refer to them, "sarmale''. Sarmale is probably our no.1 most popular 
traditional food.

Cevapi - that looks exactly like something we have here in Romania and it's 
called ''mici'' (romanians are crazy about eating mici with mustard and 
drinking beer :) ).

Baklava - we also have that in Romania (baclava).﻿

+Ogi Chan Those types of food are traditional in many countries. Just 
because some of them supposedly originate from the Ottoman Empire doesn't 
mean there are not traditional for other countries.

A traditional food is a type of food that has a long history in a specific 
country and it's cooked in the original way or in a very similar way - 
adapted by that specific country. Nobody cares and actually nobody can say 
for sure what's the exact origin of each type of dish - only in Romania we 
have like hundreds of traditional recipes.

comments.text:
As I was saying every country has their own variation of a dish. Doesn't 
mean that anyone owns it. Its just what constitutes that countries' 
cuisine. For example Sarma made in Serbia, and Sarma made in Turkey are 
vastly different in taste and texture. And also have some different 
ingredients (Exclusively soured cabbage is used as well as bacon/smoked 
ham/ smoked sausage and its cooked in a special kind of dish and at the end 
a special pan fried combination of minced paprika/peppers/flour/garlic is 
added). Thus, it is a regional dish. It is true that it originated in the 
Ottoman Empire, but it is not a part of the Turkish cuisine. So it would be 
correct to say that Serbian Sarma originated from the Ottoman Empire, but 
it would not be correct to say that it is a part of the Turkish Cuisine.

comments.text:
Actually, there was an extremely limited conflict between Slovenia and 
Yugoslavia, however it only lasted for ten days, with very limited 
casualties. I believe the "ten years" statement may have been referring to 
how long it took for relative peace to set in for all former Yugoslav 
countries, rather than the time between the first declaration of war and 
the final official war to end. In the case of official warfare, the 
conflicts lasted slightly under eight years (Ten Day War started June 27, 
1991, while Kosovo War was officially ended June 11, 1999) while, if 
counting the Insurgencies in Preševo Valley and Macedonia/FYROM, the 
conflicts did not conclude until November of 2001.

top_comment.text:
Uh.. that's all basically Turkish or Middle-Eastern food. Yes, its very 
common in areas of former Yugoslavia historically influenced by the Ottoman 
Empire, but its not indigenous "Balkan" food. The best term overall would 
probably be "Ottoman cuisine", as in the cuisine of the Ottoman Empire.

*Kefir* - a drink originating from the Caucasus region.

*Burek* and *baklava* - Greek dishes of course, originating well away from 
the Balkans peninsula: on the island of Cyprus.

*Sarma* - from the Turkish word "sarmak", "to roll up", a Turkish dish.

*Cevapi* - a Balkans evolution of the kebab, an Iranian dish adopted 
heavily by the Turks and brought with them into the Balkans. The word 
actually derives from the Iranian (Farsi) word "kabap" ("kabap" -> 
"cevap"), meaning "to fry".

*Tufahije* - an Iranian (Persian) dish historically common in the entire 
Ottoman Empire.

*Shopska salad* - a Bulgarian side-dish. So yeah, its from the Balkans, 
amazingly, but its not a former Yugoslav dish for the record.


4:29 He's right. The Balkans don't really have their own cuisine. Maybe a 
rogue meal or two, but its all basically Turkish or Italian (in Dalmatia 
and Istria) or Hungarian/German (in the north). But I admit that point is 
debateable.. who knows what it takes to have your own proper "cuisine".

I'm from "the Balkans", btw... Split, Croatia.﻿

According to cultural historians, the original name is Afghan پلو / palau 
(including Polow ) . However, it has no meaning in that language, so it 
might be a linguistic transfer from India. The cooking technique for pilaf 
was in India but only by Muslims. The oldest known mention of pilaf 
technology is available in Arabic books from the 13th century , written in 
Bagdad and in Syria. As ingredients they call meat , legumes and fruits. In 
Arabic recipe collections of the 10th century , this technique is still 
nicht.Eines the oldest proven recipes istqabuli pulaw , initially only with 
meat and chickpeas, today mostly even with almonds and raisins. This 
variant is now in Afghanistan as a national dish .

Dear Buzzfeed,
It's a nice thing that you taste different cuisines, but most of the food 
that you have tasted is Turkish food, not balkan. There may be some 
different versions but their origins are Turkish. And even the names of the 
food in Turkish like burek (originally "börek") and sarma (litterally 
"wrapping" or "rolling" the verb for"sar-" "to wrap"). Please, try visiting 
a Turkish restaurant despite of all Turkish hatred in the comments. There 
are many Turkish restaurants with good Turkish chefs in the U.S. And if you 
can, please visit Turkey as you will have the finest cuisine in the world.

Warm regards
A friend :)﻿

comments.text:
+Melba Hysa Ok, lets start from the beginning shall we... With all the bad 
blood, hatred, recent atrocities on both sides, what did you expect? Candy 
and flowers? You certainly are not that naive to believe that it would be 
any different if the game was played in Albania - at least for the part of 
shouting murderous paroles and nationalistic ambitions? I for one am more 
then sure, that it would be the same! Look, football games and stadiums 
have long ceased to be places where normal people like you and me can enjoy 
the simple fact of a wonderful game! You think that nationalism (on the 
stadiums and in general) is exclusive for your two nations? Grow up and 
grow up fast my dear because what you are saying later (up to a certain 
point) makes me believe you are no different then the hooligans them self! 
Why? That will bring us to a second part... (I am not going to comment the 
booing and shouting of murderous paroles and nationalistic ambitions - 
that's what FIFA should do...) What second half? The game was interrupted 
somewhere around the 40th minute of the first half if I am not mistaking 
and was never continued??? So let us pause here and see how this 
interruption (all hell broke loose) occurred... A drone carrying an 
autochthonous flag flew into the stadium... I have to ask you this because 
you skipped an important part... Who controlled the drone and for what 
purpose? The implications of such act regardless of country, religion and 
creed are obvious and preposterous by it self!  The flag... Now imagine the 
same situation in a game between my country (Germany) and let say Israel, 
where Israel is the host... And the flag is carrying a swastika, or "Arbeit 
macht frei", or "Mein Kampf"??? What do you thing would happen? Shalom 
aleichem perhaps? But let's get back to the "autochthonous" flag as you 
say... I have asked numerous Albanians about the symbolism of that 
particular flag and all of them here in Berlin told me (proudly) that it 
represents basically your national(istic) craving to unite all land where 
Albanians live! If my memory serves me well, NATO bombed the shit out of 
Serbia for having exactly the same intentions!?? So in general, your 
football players protected a national(istic) craving - they didn't protect 
a flag of Albania (just to recap, the game was between Serbia and Albania, 
right?) or Kosovo what could be understood as "kind" of normal (if you 
consider "normal" hoisting your flag on a drone) but an idea that caused so 
much human suffering in the beginning! No shit Sherlock, your players were 
afraid of entering the second half??? And you say that you understand this 
all was a provocation??? What is wrong with you...? The resulting beating 
of your players comes as no wonder to be honest but that goes entirely on 
the hands of Serbian authorities as their security fuckup! But the thing 
that shocked me most is the behavior of your people just after the game all 
around your  "autochthonous" regions... They were celebrating in the 
streets like they actually won the game... Flags all around, people on the 
streets shouting... I wonder who was the bigger "hooligan" that night - 
those in the stadium in Serbia, or your entire nation... Which game did 
they won?
"Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn"/ I couldn't care less for you, your 
people or Serbia as a matter of fact but if you want to comment something 
that was broadcasted live to so many people, I would consider getting your 
shit straight!

comments.author: Kalfa

top_comment.text:
My grandpa and his sisters were born in Yugoslavia and came here when they 
were young, and my mother was raised with a lot of Balkan and Scottish food 
both. A lot of the traditional dishes are so damn good. But I gotta say, 
when she makes Sarma, I make her use a friend's kitchen. For a food that 
tastes delicious, it reeks for days. You can't get that smell of boiling 
cabbage out for love or money. 
But seriously, it's so nice to see some people sampling food like this. 
Makes me think back on my Goppy and Bubbas smile.
(For the record, no, Goppy is not a traditional word for grandpa, but we 
grandkids collectively decided it was easier to say than grandpoppy. I 
dunno.)﻿

comments.text:
+Laurence Wilson I am from Bosnia and I can tell you that the food they 
were eaten was typical Balkan food. Because everything on the table - from 
burek to hurmasice - we also eat in Bosnia. Like I said, we share 
traditions and culture with the Turks, but that was not only their cuisine. 
It was ours as well. I get that you're from Bulgaria and that it's a little 
dissapointing that they didn't pay attention to your heritage and cuisine, 
but Milan was from Montenegro so I totally get that they mostly had the 
food he knows and loves. I guess we saw it from his point of view. There 
are a nice amount of countries who are a part of the Balkan and all those 
countries are so different from each other. So yeah, we do have dishes who 
are the same, but we also have so many who aren't. They couldn't put 
everything in the video I guess.

captions.text:
- [Keith] This is Henry,
and this is me, Keith.
And today we're calling cabs and Ubers

until we find someone who
isn't native to the U.S.

to tell us about their life
and take us to the restaurant

in L.A. that reminds
them the most of home.
(electronic music)
We start with Uber.

And while we wait, we
ask our sound guy Chris
a very important question.
- Who do you like better, me or Keith?
- [Keith] The Uber arrives and we load in.
- [Henry] Where are you from, Arjen?
- [Henry] You're from Iran?
- [Keith] While we head to Echo Park,
we pitch him our idea.
He's interested and has a great story,

but doesn't have time this
afternoon to be in the video.
So we part ways.
- Been great talking to you, man.
- He was sneaking across borders
to get to America, essentially?

- [Henry] Yeah, and like
the food he was describing,

I was like fuck, just
come on, agree to it.

- [Keith] We call a
cab using the app Curb.
- This app is terrible.

- [Keith] We take a moment
to appreciate the beauty
of Echo Park, and we get in the next cab.
This cabbie is literally the most
crotchety old man to ever drive a car.
He takes us to Chinatown
and we get out as quickly as possible.

We decide to stretch our legs
before calling another Uber.

During our walk, Henry finds
a truck filled with grapes,

and immediately gets a grape
seed stuck in his front teeth.
We call another Uber.
We get in and meet Thomas,
who thinks we're making a student film.
Thomas does not fit our specifications,
but he was awesome all the same.

We continue toward downtown
and we passed a building

that sells ink, copies,
storage and waffles?
We get out, stretch our legs again,

and then we foolishly
entered an intersection
without enough time to cross.

- [Henry] (singing)
Running across the street.

- [Keith] We're getting very
hungry and a little bit crazy.
- I'm about to call an Uber.
He's in a Honda Odyssey.

- [Keith] An Odyssey is
a good sort of metaphor
for what we're doing here.

The Uber arrives and we hop
in, hoping this is the one.
- [Keith] He seems awesome.

So we ask if he wants to
be a part of our video.
- Well how come you came to America?
- [Keith] The more we talked with him,
the more we loved Milan.
So to see if he's a true Angelino,
I ask him one more important question.
Whats his favorite fast food?
- [Henry] Perfect.

- [Keith] We arrive at Aroma
Cafe, where Henry, Chris,

and I will eat Balkan
food for the first time.

Henry and Milan proceed
to order way too much food

and our waitress kindly
acts like it's normal.

First we have kefir, a
milk and yogurt drink.

- Cheers!
- Cheers, guys.
- Uh, it's really interesting.

It is not sweet at all,
which I really like.
It just tastes like, wholesome.

- What do you think of it, Chris?
(Chris laughs)
- It's really tart but I really like it.
- I prefer normal milk.
Kefir is normally paired with burek,
a savory pastry.

- It's like, um, spanikopita.
- Exactly.
Very, very similar to Greek.
- I love how warm it is.
- It's very simple, but very delicious.
Next up sarma, which is smoked ground lamb

with rice wrapped in cabbage
and grape leaves. - Wow.
We don't have anything...
Like the meat tastes like really,
sort of fatty taste to the meat.
- So much flavor.

- It tastes like I'm coming
home for the holidays. - Yeah.

- Yeah, get that.
- I can't get enough of this.

- You don't find many dishes
like this in other countries.

- No, no-- - This is typical
Yugoslavian, or Balkan, food.

Little bit of vegetables,
and meat, and bread.
Bread is really common with everything.
- [Keith] At one point in our feasting,
Milan has to go take a call

while we continue to eat so much food.
- Woah!

I know she said it was lamb,
but it tastes like bacon.

- I get with this bread,
'cause the bread's made here...
- It's like the kind of bread I feel bad

making a sandwich with too,
because the bread itself
is like so delicious on its own.
- [Keith] This was just a plate of meat.

- [Henry] A plate of
meat on a bed of onions.
- [Keith] Yeah.

- [Henry] Like pretty smokey,
which is really like...

I guess I never even
thought that the Balkans

had their own cuisine, which
is super ignorant of me.
- [Keith] It's like smokey, but the taste
is a lot like a gyro meat.

- [Keith] Milan comes
back, only to let us know

that he needs to get
to a meeting downtown.

So we say our goodbyes,
and then we continue
to demolish all the food we ordered.

As well as Turkish coffee with
a piece of Turkish delight,
a sugar-soaked and baklava-stuffed apple,
this sweet, cake-like pastry, and baklava.

- Oh, man!
- Is it hot, or delicious?
- No, it's so good!
What the fuck is happening?
- [Keith] This is candy.
- Right now I feel like I could fight
like seven donkeys at once.
- [Keith] It was time to go.

We thanked our server, and
the owner of Aroma Cafe,
and headed into our last Uber home.
The day was a success,

and we'd like to thank
Milan one more time.

He helped us experience
food that was foreign to us
after he spent 30 years raising a family
in a culture foreign to him.
Every driver has a story,
and today we got to experience one.

- [Henry] Can i just
say that Milan is like
the coolest fuckin dude I've ever met.
- [Keith] He's so cool.
- He just like wants to talk about food,

which is what I want to talk
about all the time. - Yeah.
- It's amazing.

title: Americans Try Balkan Food With Their Uber Driver
